items.message:
River levels are rising steadily on the Middlesbrough Becks. Heavy rainfall has fell overnight and further rainfall will continue into the morning. Rainfall is expected to ease in the afternoon. 
Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the Middlesbrough Becks, with low lying land expected to be most affected, particularly around riverside footpaths and low lying land and roads.
We do not expect to issue a flood warning and no property flooding is expected. 
We will continue to monitor levels closely.
This message will be updated by 06:00 PM on 23/07/2023, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Upper River Irwell catchment with Oldham, Bolton, Rochdale, Haslingden, Ramsbottom and Rawtenstall

floodArea.county: Blackburn with Darwen, Bolton, Bury, Lancashire, Oldham, Rochdale

items.message: River levels are rising on the River Irwell. Areas most at risk include low lying land and roads around the Rivers Beal, Roch and Croal, Limy Water and their tributaries. No property flooding is expected. Flooding is possible at low lying land and roads around the Rivers Beal, Roch and Croal, Limy Water and their tributaries from 08:00 AM on 23/07/2023. Further rainfall is forecast throughout the morning. We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. This message will be updated by 17:00 PM on 23/07/2023, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Lower River Irwell catchment including areas in Greater Manchester

floodArea.county: Bolton, Bury, Manchester, Oldham, Rochdale, Salford, Tameside, Trafford

items.message: River levels are rising on the River Irwell due to persistent rainfall. No property flooding is expected. Flooding is possible at low lying land and roads around the Rivers Irk and Medlock, Wince and Worsley Brooks and their tributaries from 09:00 AM on 23/07/2023. We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. This message will be updated by 17:00 PM on 23/07/2023, or as the situation changes.

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Calder, Walsden Water, Hebden Water

items.message:
This flood alert remains in force due to elevated river levels in the Upper River Calder Catchment between Todmorden and Brighouse. Despite further persistent rain on Sunday, levels are expected to steadily fall later this morning as most of the heavier rain has passed. River levels are currently forecast to peak in Todmorden around 07:00 today, Sunday 23rd July 2023, and at around 10:00 in Brighouse. This persistent rain could lead to some localised surface water flooding. We are not currently expecting to issue any flood warnings but will be closely monitoring the situation. 
Please stay aware of your surroundings and do not put yourself at risk. Avoid using low lying footpaths and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.
For a more detailed weather forecast for your area please see the Met Office website at www.metoffice.gov.uk.
This message will be updated by 15:10 hours on Sunday 23rd July 2023, or as the situation changes.

floodArea.riverOrSea: Ings Beck, Alverthorpe Beck, Balne Beck, Oakenshaw Beck

items.message:
This flood alert remains in force due to elevated river levels in the Ings Beck Catchment in Wakefield. Despite further persistent rain on Sunday, 23rd July 2023, levels are expected to steadily fall from later this morning as most of the heavier rain has passed. This persistent rain could lead to some localised surface water flooding. We are not currently expecting to issue any flood warnings but will be closely monitoring the situation. 
Please stay aware of your surroundings and do not put yourself at risk. Avoid using low lying footpaths and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.
For a more detailed weather forecast for your area please see the Met Office website at www.metoffice.gov.uk.
This message will be updated by 15:20, or as the situation changes.

"River levels are forecast to rise at the Pillings Lock river gauge as a result of recent persistent rainfall.  Consequently, the risk of flooding remains.  Areas most at risk are low-lying agricultural land and roads including Slash Lane at Sileby and the Mountsorrel to Sileby road.   
  We expect river levels to remain high for the next 2 or 3 days
We are closely monitoring the situation.  
Please plan driving routes to avoid low-lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded and avoid using low-lying footpaths near local watercourses.  
This message will be updated by 20:00 this evening, 23/07/23, or as the situation changes."

River levels have risen overnight on the River Wyre, River Brock due to heavy rainfall. Areas most at risk include Rivers Wyre, Calder and Brock and other watercourses from Abbeystead to Catterall including Scorton, Garstang, Bilsborrow, Ainspool and Churchtown. Flooding is possible at Rivers Wyre, Calder and Brock and other watercourses from Abbeystead to Catterall including Scorton, Garstang, Bilsborrow, Ainspool and Churchtown. Further rainfall is forecast throughout the morning. River levels are expected to remain high throughout the morning on 23/07/2023. We are operating flood denfeces in the catchment and will continue to monitor levels closely. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. This message will be updated by 05:00 PM on 23/07/2023, or as the situation changes.

River levels have risen overnight on the River Wyre due to heavy rainfall. Areas most at risk include River Wyre, River Cocker, Pilling Water and other watercourses from Catterall to Fleetwood, including St Michaels and Great Eccleston and Preesall. Flooding is possible at River Wyre, River Cocker, Pilling Water and other watercourses from Catterall to Fleetwood, including St Michaels and Great Eccleston and Preesall. Further rainfall is forecast throughout the morning and river levels are expected to remain high. We are operating flood defences in the catchment and will continue to monitor levels closely. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. This message will be updated by 05:00 AM on 23/07/2023, or as the situation changes.

This flood alert remains in force due to elevated river levels in the Lower River Calder Catchment between Mirfield and Methley. Further persistent rain, heavy at times, is expected through today, Sunday 23rd July 2023. Currently, river levels are forecast to peak in Mirfield around 13:00 hours today, and through Wakefield from 15:00 hours onwards. This persistent rain could lead to some localised surface water flooding. We are not currently expecting to issue any flood warnings but will be closely monitoring the situation. 
Please stay aware of your surroundings and do not put yourself at risk. Avoid using low lying footpaths and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.
For a more detailed weather forecast for your area please see the Met Office website at www.metoffice.gov.uk.
This message will be updated by 17:10 on 23rd July 2023 or as the situation changes.

River levels will rise steadily on the River Calder and River Hyndburn due to heavy rainfall. Areas most at risk include Rivers Calder, Brun, Don and Pendlewater, from Laneshaw Bridge to the river Ribble including Trawden, Burnley, Nelson, Colne, Accrington and Whalley. Flooding is possible at Rivers Calder, Hyndburn, Brun, Don and Pendlewater, from Laneshaw Bridge to the river Ribble including Trawden, Burnley, Nelson, Colne, Accrington and Whalley from 09:30 AM on 23/07/2023. Further rainfall is forecast throughout the morning. River levels are expected to remain high. We will continue to monitor levels closely. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. This message will be updated by 05:00 PM on 23/07/2023, or as the situation changes.

River levels will rise steadily on the River Ribble and River Darwen due to heavy rainfall. Areas most at risk include River Ribble from Samlesbury and the River Darwen from Darwen including Blackburn, Preston, Walton-Le-Dale, Pleasington and Higher Walton. Flooding is possible at River Ribble from Samlesbury and the River Darwen from Darwen including Blackburn, Preston, Walton-Le-Dale, Pleasington and Higher Walton from noon on 23/07/2023. Further rainfall is forecast throughout the day. River levels are expected to remain high. We will continue to monitor levels closely. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. This message will be updated by 05:00 PM on 23/07/2023, or as the situation changes.

This flood alert remains in force due to elevated river levels in the Earby area following a spell of heavy rain overnight. Despite further persistent rain on Sunday, 23rd July 2023, levels are expected to steadily fall from later this morning as most of the heavier rain has passed. River levels are currently forecast to peak on Earby Beck through Earby around 07:00 and on the New Cut around 10:00. This persistent rain could lead to some localised surface water flooding. We are not currently expecting to issue any flood warnings but will be closely monitoring the situation. 
Please stay aware of your surroundings and do not put yourself at risk. Avoid using low lying footpaths and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.
For a more detailed weather forecast for your area please see the Met Office website at www.metoffice.gov.uk.
This message will be updated by 15:30, or as the situation changes.

River levels will rise steadily on the River Alt due to heavy rainfall. Areas most at risk include River Alt and other watercourses from Huyton to Hightown including, Kirkby, Fazakerley, Maghull, Formby, Aughton, Sefton and Lunt. Flooding is possible at River Alt and other watercourses from Huyton to Hightown including, Kirkby, Fazakerley, Maghull, Formby, Aughton, Sefton and Lunt from noon on 23/07/2023. Further rainfall is forecast throughout the day. River levels are expected to remain high. We will continue to monitor levels closely. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. This message will be updated by 05:00 PM on 23/07/2023, or as the situation changes.

items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
items.message: The risk of flooding from the River Dart has now reduced, and river levels are falling below levels of concern. No further flooding to fields and roads is expected, however there may be standing water seen for several days.

River levels have risen on the River Douglas due to heavy rainfall.
Areas most at risk include River Douglas and other watercourses from Parbold to Tarleton including Rufford, Mawdesley, Croston and Moss Side.
Flooding is possible at River Douglas and other watercourses from Parbold to Tarleton including Rufford, Mawdesley, Croston and Moss Side from 08:30 AM on 23/07/2023.
Further rainfall is forecast this morning.
River levels are forecast to rise.
We will continue to monitor levels closely.
Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.
This message will be updated by 05:00 PM on 23/07/2023, or as the situation changes.

River levels are rising on the Upper River Aire catchment due to persistent rainfall through yesterday, 22nd July 2023, and overnight into today, 23rd July 2023. Areas most at risk include the River Aire from Gargrave to Stockbridge. Washlands at Cononley have started to fill. Further persistent rainfall is forecast throughout today, Sunday 23rd July 2023, which could lead to some localised surface water flooding. We are not currently expecting to issue any flood warnings but will be closely monitoring the situation. We currently expect the Aire to peak at Kildwick late this afternoon and evening before starting to fall again overnight. 
Please stay aware of your surroundings and do not put yourself at risk. Avoid using low lying footpaths and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.
For a more detailed weather forecast for your area please see the Met Office website at www.metoffice.gov.uk.
This message will be updated by 20:40 hours on 23/07/2023, or as the situation changes.
